prompt:
Introduction
International business is an increasingly complex field that requires a deep understanding of the intricacies of multinational companies entering foreign markets. Walmart’s investment opportunity in Italy provides an excellent case study to apply Dunning’s eclectic paradigm. We will use OLI framework to critically assess Walmart’s investment opportunity in Italy. This analysis will consider the ownership, location, and internalization components of the OLI paradigm, along with cultural and legal factors that impact Walmart’s operations in Italy. Understanding the complexities of multinational companies’ investments in foreign markets is essential, and this essay aims to provide insights that will assist Walmart in making strategic decisions that contribute to its global success.


Dunning’s eclectic paradigm and critique of OLI
Dunning’s eclectic paradigm is a framework used to understand the motives behind multinational companies’ investments in foreign markets. The model is based on three components; ownership, location, and internalization (OLI). According to Dunning (1980), ownership refers to the ownership-specific advantages of the multinational company, location reflects the advantages of the foreign country in which the investment is made, and internalization refers to the advantages of managing the investment internally. However, while Dunning’s eclectic paradigm has become popular in international business literature, its efficacy has been called into question. Critics such as Cantwell and Narula (2001) and Zaheer (1995) have raised concerns about Dunning’s eclectic paradigm, or the OLI framework. They argue that the theory overlooks cultural and institutional disparities across nations, which could result in its inability to clarify why a specific strategy may thrive in one country but fail in another. Moreover, these analysts, including Rugman (1981) and Eden and Dai (1996), also assert that the OLI framework does not consider the importance of the host country’s market structure and how it may affect the multinational corporation’s (MNC) operations and success.
Recent studies have called for a revision of the OLI paradigm, including the integration of contemporary theories such as institutional theory, resource-based theory, and competitors’ analysis (Bellak et al., 2018). For example, Peng (2017) argues that it is necessary to integrate institutional factors into the OLI paradigm to effectively explain why some strategies might work in some countries and not in others. Similarly, Verbeke (2013) emphasizes that the OLI framework should incorporate a network perspective to capture the dynamics of the relationships between the MNC and different stakeholders. In addition to the criticisms of the OLI framework, some scholars argue that the model overlooks the importance of global value chains (GVCs) and the role they play in multinational corporations’ investments (Gereffi et al., 2019). With the advent of technology and new forms of digital trade, GVCs play a crucial role in multinational corporations’ operations and strategies.
Therefore, while Dunning’s eclectic paradigm has become a crucial framework for analyzing multinational corporations’ investments in foreign markets, recent studies highlight its weaknesses and call for the integration of contemporary theories to capture the complexities of the current global business environment.


Ownership
The ownership component within Dunning’s eclectic paradigm (OLI) framework emphasizes the assessment of a firm’s competitive advantages based on its unique resources or capabilities (Dunning, 2000). Walmart, being the world’s largest retailer, has consistently utilized its considerable resources and capabilities to achieve global success (Fortune Global 500, 2021). Some of these resources include its economies of scale, vast distribution networks, and advanced supply chain management techniques (Pappas et al., 2020). In theory, these ownership advantages should provide Walmart with a strong foundation for growth potential within the Italian market. It is essential to focus on Walmart’s strengths- such as its capacity to leverage economies of scale to increase market share, as evidenced in other markets - and weaknesses, while examining the competition in the Italian retail sector.

For example, Walmart’s economies of scale have allowed the company to reduce costs and gain a competitive advantage through various methods, such as bulk purchasing, vertical integration, and streamlining supply chain processes. In China, Walmart utilized these advantages to rapidly expand its presence, becoming one of the largest foreign retailers in the country. By offering lower prices and more extensive product selections than domestic competitors, Walmart attracted millions of Chinese consumers and increased its market share (Chan & Zhang, 2011).

With its strengths in cost control, distribution, and supply chain management, Walmart has the potential to confront the challenges posed by the Italian market, such as adapting to the culturally-sensitive environment and catering to the preferences of Italian consumers that value quality and authenticity. To overcome these barriers, Walmart can leverage its resources to invest in research and collaborate with local suppliers to ensure quality, locally-sourced products while maintaining its low-price guarantee. This approach can help the company to build trust and loyalty among Italian customers, which is crucial for market penetration in Italy (Hitt et al., 2011).

Walmart’s ownership advantages also empower the company to explore strategic alliances, mergers, or acquisitions in Italy, potentially providing entry into the Italian retail sector. As mentioned previously, Walmart’s partnership with Grupo Éxito, a Colombian retail company, in 1994 demonstrates the company’s ability to successfully enter foreign markets through strategic collaborations (Gaviria & Meléndez, 2006).

In sum, Walmart’s ownership advantages, particularly its economies of scale and supply chain capabilities, play a crucial role in the company’s potential success in the Italian market. By focusing on these strengths, Walmart can develop a strategic plan that addresses the unique challenges and preferences of the Italian retail landscape. This will allow the company to better position itself within Italy, potentially achieving similar success that it has accomplished in other foreign markets. However, it is essential for Walmart to carefully consider and balance all aspects of the OLI framework, including location and internalization advantages, to build a comprehensive strategy for its investment or operations in Italy.


Location
Foremost, the cultural aspect of Italy is an important factor that can impact Walmart’s entry into the market. As a country with a rich and unique cultural heritage, Italy is characterized by strong local traditions and habits in consumer behavior, which may pose challenges to Walmart’s standardization strategies (Perri et al., 2014). For example, Italian consumers tend to place significant value on local products, artisanal craftsmanship, and small-scale retail operations (Cappellini et al., 2016) which could present a disadvantage for Walmart, as they may struggle to gain acceptance in the market. Moreover, some critics argue that Walmart’s emphasis on low prices and high volume might not resonate well with the preferences of Italian consumers, who typically prioritize quality and authenticity over cost savings (Cainelli et al., 2015).

Economically, Italy is a mature market with a relatively high competition in the retail sector. Walmart is likely to face strong competition from domestic retailers such as Conad and Coop, which have extensive experience in the local market and deep relationships with local suppliers. Additionally, international retail chains such as Carrefour and Lidl have a presence in the Italian market, which increases the level of competition Walmart is likely to face. Additionally, the country has been facing prolonged economic stagnation, with the retail industry being affected significantly by a lack of consumer demand and decreasing purchasing power (Reilly, 2021). In this context, Walmart could face challenges in achieving its growth and profitability targets, as the overall propensity for consumption in the country remains subdued (Banchero et al., 2019). Furthermore, the highly fragmented nature of the Italian retail market, with a large presence of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), can further intensify competition and make market penetration more difficult for Walmart (Valentina et al., 2017).
Legally speaking, the regulatory environment in Italy can be complex, and difficulties in navigating the business landscape may pose challenges for Walmart’s entry and operations in the market (Del Baldo et al., 2019). For instance, bureaucratic processes related to permits and licenses might slow down Walmart’s expansion plans in the country, while stringent labor laws and regulations could potentially affect the flexibility and cost of its workforce (Mangiarotti et al., 2016). Additionally, as highlighted by Meliszewski and Lupo (2019), the country’s stringent environmental regulations might also require Walmart to adapt its operational model to comply with local standards, potentially increasing its overall cost base.
However, despite the mentioned challenges, Walmart could leverage its global scale and supply chain expertise to negotiate favorable deals with Italian suppliers, thereby potentially offsetting some of the location disadvantages (Dunning, 2008). Furthermore, as noted by Hernandez et al. (2017), Walmart has been successful in adapting its offering and operational strategies to local market conditions in the past, and such experience could prove useful in the Italian context. For example, Walmart could focus on enhancing its private label offerings with high-quality, locally sourced products, which might better resonate with Italian consumers and allow the company to differentiate itself from local competition (Donvito et al., 2016).

Overall, while cultural, economic, and legal factors might pose significant challenges, the company’s international experience and capabilities can potentially be leveraged to overcome these hurdles and achieve a competitive position in the market and to do this, Walmart would need to maintain a careful balance between the standardization of its global strategies and the adaptation to the unique features of the Italian market.


Internationalisation
Internationalisation offers numerous benefits for companies, such as economies of scale, improved efficiency, and better control over operations. However, it also comes with challenges, including added costs, risks, and the need to adapt to local market conditions. For Walmart, a successful entry into the Italian market requires leveraging its internal resources and capabilities while addressing various internal and external factors.

One primary advantage of internationalisation for Walmart in Italy is the potential for economies of scale, leading to increased efficiency and reduced costs. By expanding its business and opening more stores, Walmart can spread its fixed costs across a larger sales volume, lowering the average cost per unit and potentially improving profit margins (Mennillo, 2012). Furthermore, operating on a larger scale allows Walmart to take advantage of its significant bargaining power with suppliers, securing better deals that can lower input costs and lead to price competitiveness in the Italian retail market (Bloomberg, 2019). In addition to economies of scale, internationalisation allows Walmart to better control its operations and tailor its policies to match its business needs within Italy. Such control enables Walmart to gain a deeper understanding of local culture and consumer behaviour, allowing the company to customise its marketing strategies, product offerings, and pricing in a way that appeals to Italian consumers (Mennillo, 2012).

Despite these advantages, internationalisation also presents several disadvantages for Walmart entering the Italian market. The lack of local knowledge can lead to suboptimal decision-making, which can negatively impact the company’s business performance. Additionally, establishing and managing new stores in a foreign country may require significant investment and resources, as well as the need to navigate complex regulatory frameworks, adapt to local business practices, and avoid cultural misunderstandings that could harm Walmart’s reputation (Mennillo, 2012).

To succeed in Italy, Walmart needs to leverage its core capabilities and resources, including its advanced supply chain and logistics systems, strong brand recognition, marketing expertise, and data analytics and optimisation strategies (Bloomberg, 2019). However, the company also faces potential barriers to internationalisation, such as Italy’s strict regulatory environment, competition from well-established retailers, and cultural differences that may impact consumer preferences (Lorenzani, 2016). A critical analysis of Walmart’s internationalisation strategy indicates that while it has been successful in other foreign markets, the Italian market presents unique challenges requiring the company to adapt to the specific regulatory, cultural, and economic environment. These challenges and disadvantages can be mitigated through a thorough understanding of the local market, effective management of resources, and the development of targeted strategies that cater to Italian consumers.

Overall, Walmart’s internationalisation strategy has the potential to be successful in Italy, as long as it effectively addresses the challenges presented by the Italian market. By leveraging its strengths and adapting to the local business landscape, Walmart can position itself for growth and potentially secure a dominant position within the Italian retail sector.

Conclusion
In conclusion, Walmart's investment opportunity in Italy serves as an excellent case study to apply Dunning's eclectic paradigm. However, recent studies have highlighted weaknesses in the OLI framework, emphasizing the need for the integration of contemporary theories to capture the complexities of the current global business environment. The ownership component of the OLI framework emphasizes the assessment of a firm's competitive advantages based on its unique resources or capabilities, which determines the extent to which a firm can exploit its ownership advantages or disadvantages in the foreign market. In theory, Walmart's ownership advantages should offer significant growth potential within the Italian market. However, cultural differences, the entrenched nature of local businesses, and the highly competitive landscape may limit Walmart's success in the Italian market. Therefore, a comprehensive analysis of Walmart's ownership, location, and internalization advantages is essential to make strategic decisions that contribute to its global success.

prompt:
翻译：  Remote Slave Operation
The Bidirectional control channel provides a mechanism to read or write I2C registers in remote devices over the
FPD-Link III interface. The I2C Master located at the Deserializer must support I2C clock stretching. Accesses to
serializer or remote slave devices over the Bidirectional Control Channel will result in clock stretching to allow for
response time across the link. The DS90UB936-Q1 acts as an I2C slave on the local bus, forwards read and
write requests to the remote device, and returns the response from the remote device to the local I2C bus. To
allow for the propagation and regeneration of the I2C transaction at the remote device, the DS90UB936-Q1 will
stretch the I2C clock while waiting for the remote response. To communicate with a remote slave device, the Rx
Port which is intended for messaging also must be selected in register 0x4C. The I2C address of the currently
selected RX Port serializer will be populated in register 0x5B of the DS90UB936-Q1. The BCC_CONFIG register
0x58 also must have bit 6, I2C_PASS_THROUGH set to one. If enabled, local I2C transactions with valid
address decode will then be forwarded through the Bidirectional Control Channel to the remote I2C bus. When
I2C PASS THROUGH is set, the deserializer will only propagate messages that the DS90UB936-Q1 recognizes,
such as the registered serializer alias address (SER ALIAS), or any registered remote slave alias attached to the
serializer I2C bus (SLAVE ALIAS) assigned to the specific Rx Port0 or Port 1. Setting PASS THROUGH ALL and
AUTO ACK are less common use cases and primarily used for debugging I2C messaging as they will
respectively pass all addresses regardless of valid I2C address (PASS_THROUGH_ALL) and acknowledge all
I2C commands without waiting for a response from serializer (AUTO_ACK)
label: False

"Item #: SCP-305

Special Containment Procedures: SCP-305 is presently immobile. Site-305 has been constructed around its present location, a wooded canyon near [REDACTED], and is staffed by at least seven (7) personnel who have prior experience with SCP-305 and proved resistant to its effects. The remainder of the station crew should be rotated on a weekly basis. SCP-305’s effect grows weaker if human subjects are exposed to it for extended periods of time; therefore, a resistant subject should be exposed to it for at least three (3) hours daily.

SCP-305’s effects are greatly magnified in individuals with feelings of guilt (particularly over crimes) or mental instability. Therefore, Site-305 is staffed exclusively by non-D-class researchers and agents who are screened for criminal records and mental instability. Any personnel who begin to hear whispered compliments must be transferred out immediately. If symptoms persist after removal, frontal lobotomy [DATA EXPUNGED]

The actual containment chamber of SCP-305 is constructed of standard materials and offset from the rest of the station by a five (5) meter “buffer zone” to protect normal staff from the worst of SCP-305’s effects.

Site-305 broadcasts a constant “status normal” signal to Site-19. If Site-305 becomes compromised during a containment breach, this signal will cease and a heavily armed containment team will immediately be dispatched to the location.

Instances of SCP-305-1 are extremely dangerous and should be terminated on sight without attempting containment.

As of ██/██/200█, all attempts to extract samples from SCP-305 for study are forbidden. (See Addendum 305-1)

Description: SCP-305 is a rock formation of approximately humanoid size and shape. Remote recordings of SCP-305 show that it remains stationary at all times, even when interacting with human subjects.

When viewed by a sentient observer, SCP-305 appears to be a mobile, animate humanoid of indeterminate sex. This manifestation is formed of cracked rock similar to SCP-305’s physical form, and while it is faceless, subjects report that the cracks all over SCP-305’s surface begin to resemble human lips and ears as it moves.

Human subjects who make visual contact with this manifestation hear “whispering” voices, although recording equipment in the area picks up nothing and the phenomenon is observed even in subjects who are deaf from birth. SCP-305 will initially ingratiate itself with the subject by whispering compliments. During this phase the subject experiences feelings of friendliness and trust toward SCP-305. These sensations seem unrelated to the actual content of the “compliments,” which ranges from ‘off’ to nonsensical and disturbing. A short list of reported compliments is included:

“You have beautiful eye-sockets.”
“[REDACTED] every one of your fingers”
“Your neck appears unusually flexible.”
In the second phase, the subject begins to hear many voices emanating from SCP-305. At this point the whispers become critical, attempting to insult the subject or undermine the subject’s self esteem, especially by playing on the subject’s guilty conscience. Like the compliments, these insults make little sense when recounted, but have a profound psychological effect, driving the subject to suicide before the final phase in 20% of cases. If the subject is removed from SCP-305’s presence during phase two, the subject will hallucinate that these insults are emanating from mouth-like cracks that appear to form on the ground, walls and ceiling.

In the third and final phase, the voices will abruptly stop. 2 to 10 hours from the cessation of hallucinations, SCP-305’s humanoid manifestation will appear and kill the subject. Causes of death are varied but include severe cardiac infarct, muscle spasm leading to severing of the spinal column, diaphragm paralysis and [REDACTED].

A subject who dies of any cause after the beginning of the second phase [DATA EXPUNGED] followed by the emergence of an instance of SCP-305-1 from the corpse. SCP-305-1 are humanoids slightly smaller than SCP-305 itself. Unlike SCP-305, SCP-305-1 seem to be made of a smooth hard white substance and the lips and mouths on their surfaces are extremely lifelike. SCP-305-1 have the same abilities as SCP-305, and although they are created with a very short range of 2 meters, this range increases exponentially over time. SCP-305-1 move at 30 km/h and seem naturally drawn in a direct line toward the nearest densely populated area, presumably in an attempt to further propagate themselves. SCP-305-1 are highly resistant to bullets and cutting weapons — elimination teams should be equipped with heavy ballistics and explosives.

In subjects who have entered stage two, manifestation of SCP-305-1 can only be prevented by removal of 80% [DATA EXPUNGED].

Addendum 305-1:
On ██/██/200█, Foundation personnel used a remote-controlled device to extract a sample of SCP-305’s rock structure. SCP-305 began to emit loud grinding noises and a low growling sound. Existing cracks in the rock formation deepened and several new ones formed in the vicinity of the removed rock sample. SCP-305 then moved its "arms" upward slightly and slid one foot, about ten centimeters, across the ground as if taking a step, shedding rock-fragments as it moved before returning to its stationary state. Following this event, the range of SCP-305’s psychic influence tripled, resulting in several [DATA EXPUNGED]. Sample proved to be ordinary sedimentary rock, consistent with the surrounding area.

Follow up X-ray scans of the formation itself reveal the presence of [REDACTED], suggesting that the "rock formation" may actually be an imprisoned instance of [DATA EXPUNGED].

Upgrade to Keter requested, pending."

import streamlit as st
import pandas as pd
import requests
import json

import altair as alt

loader = instaloader.Instaloader()

# For login

password = ""

loader.context.request_timeout = (9, 15)  # Increase request timeout
access_token = ""
account_id = ""

def load_media_info(access_token, account_id):
    base_url = f"https://graph.facebook.com/v11.0/{account_id}/media"
    params = {
        "fields": "id,media_type,media_url,thumbnail_url,permalink,caption,timestamp,like_count,comments_count,insights.metric(impressions,reach,engagement)",
        "access_token": access_token
    }

    items = []
    while base_url:
        response = requests.get(base_url, params=params)
        data = json.loads(response.text)

        items.extend(data["data"])

        if "paging" in data and "next" in data["paging"]:
            base_url = data["paging"]["next"]
            params = {}
        else:
            base_url = None

    return pd.DataFrame(items)

df = load_media_info(access_token, account_id)
if 'thumbnail_url' not in df.columns:
    df['thumbnail_url'] = df['media_url']
df['thumbnail_url'] = df.apply(lambda x: x["media_url"] if x["media_type"] == "IMAGE" else x["thumbnail_url"], axis=1)

df["id"] = df["timestamp"]
df["id"] = df["id"].apply(lambda x: datetime.datetime.strptime(x.split("+")[0], "%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S").strftime("%Y%m%d"))

df = df.sort_values("timestamp", ascending=False)
df["id_rank"] = [f"_{len(list(group))}" for _, group in groupby(df["id"])]
df["id"] += df["id_rank"]

menu = ["Content", "Analytics"]
choice = st.sidebar.radio("Menu", menu)

def process_caption(caption):
    description_start = 0
    description_end = len(caption)
    if "Description:" in caption:
        description_start = caption.find("Description:") + len("Description:")
    if "Tags:" in caption:
        description_end = caption.find("Tags:")
    caption = caption[description_start:description_end].strip()
    return caption

if choice == "Content":
    selected_id = st.sidebar.selectbox("Select Post", df["id"].unique())
    selected_data = df[df["id"] == selected_id].iloc[0]
    image_url = selected_data["media_url"] if selected_data["media_type"] == "IMAGE" else selected_data["thumbnail_url"]
    image_response = requests.get(image_url)
    image = Image.open(BytesIO(image_response.content))

    caption = process_caption(selected_data['caption'])
    st.image(image, caption=caption, width=300)

    likes = selected_data["like_count"]
    
    try:
        insights = selected_data['insights']
    except KeyError:
        impressions = 0
    else:
        try:
            impressions = insights[0]['values'][0]['value']
        except (KeyError, IndexError):
            impressions = 0

    if impressions != 0:
        percentage = (likes * 100) / impressions
        st.write(f"いいね: {likes} (インプレッションに対する割合: {percentage:.1f}%)")
    else:
        st.write(f"いいね: {likes}")

    st.write(f"コメント数: {selected_data['comments_count']}")

    # Get comments and usernames
    try:

        post = instaloader.Post.from_shortcode(loader.context, shortcode)
        comments = post.get_comments

'''

The above image was captured from UV light analysis of the 1% agarose gel prepared in 1X TAE

1Kb plus DNA ladder RTU (FroggoBI0- BIOHELIX), 5 µL loaded as standard whilst the well
labelled 2 contains the digested genomic DNA (10 µL digested sample + 2 µL loading dye). The
above gel electrophoresis was run at 120 V for 20 minutes. Genomic uncut was not loaded
which was considered an error. Moreover, there were no bands at all and the problem was low
concentration of genomic DNA.
It was noticed that since INtRON RedSafeTM requires at minimum 50 ng/ µL of the sample
concentration to give any visualization detection effects, the above gel electrophoresis was
unsuccessful. This is because the concentration of originally isolated genomic Top10 DNA was
already quite low with 33.2 ng/ µL and while preparing the digestion reaction with total volume
of 35 µL we used 10 µL of the genomic DNA which implies that our genomic was diluted. Not
only this when we loaded 10 µL digested sample with 2 µL loading dye it further diluted. As per
this, the concentration of loaded sample was 33.2 ng/ µL which is very less than 50 ng/ µL as
per the RedSafeTM to work efficiently.
Calculations of digested sample concentration:
(33.2 ng / µL × 10 µL in digestion) / (10 µL while loading) = 33.2 ng/ µL

was not successful due to plating issue. There is inefficient uptake of DNA by host organism

Part B write up 12
Jetul and Japneet April 9, 2023
Image 6: Third 1% gel electrophoresis performed using HindIII and BamHI.
The above image represents the picture captured of 1% gel electrophoresis run for around 45
minutes at 120 V under UV light. This is the third gel that contained a new digestion reaction
containing the genomic DNA. The gel was prepared in 1X TAE buffer with 2.5 µL INtRON
RedSafeTM along with 6X loading dye used for sample preparations. Well labelled 1 contained
the 10 µL of 1Kb plus DNA ladder RTU (FroggoBI0- BIOHELIX), well labelled 2 contained the
undigested genomic Top10 (10 µL + 6X loading dye), well labelled 3 contained digested genomic
with BamHI and HindIII (10 µL + 6X loading dye), well labelled 4 contains the undigested
plasmid (10 µL + 6X loading dye) and well labelled 5 contains the digested plasmid with BamHI
and HindIII (10 µL + 6X loading dye).
Image 7: Information regarding the total length of the genomic Top 10 DNA using restriction
analyzer
1 2 3 4 5 1 kb DNA ladder Undigested genomic Digested genomic Undigested pUC19 Digested pUC19
Part B write up 13
Jetul and Japneet April 9, 2023
The above image provides information related to the total length of the genomic Top 10 DNA
that is 4537 bp. The tool used for this was restriction analyzer. It also shows that BamHI cuts at
2 different sites on genomic DNA. The cutting positions are 180 and 2865. These sites give very
big fragments that can be seen as smear in image 2.
This enzyme cuts at 662 on pUC19 and creates sticky ends. The total size of the plasmid is 2686
bp. If we incorporate this plasmid inside a host mentioned above, it gives a smear. There are
also chances that host could not uptake the DNA containing rspL gene.
Image 8: Information regarding the total length of the genomic Top 10 DNA and cutting
positions using HindIII and BamHI enzymes using restriction analyzer.
The above image provides information related to the total length of the genomic Top 10 DNA
that is 4537 bp. The tool used for this was restriction analyzer. It also shows that BamHI cuts at
2 different sites on genomic DNA and HindIII cuts at 4130 site on genomic DNA. The cutting
positions for BamHI are 180 and 2865 and for HindIII is 4130. We used HindIII to make sure that
our fragment contains rspL gene.
Image 9: Information regarding the total length of the plasmid DNA using restriction analyzer
Part B write up 14
Jetul and Japneet April 9, 2023
The above image provides information related to the pUC19 plasmid DNA that is 2686 bp long.
The tool used for this was restriction analyzer. It also shows that BamHI cuts at 662 position on
plasmid DNA and HindIII cuts at 632 positions. Since we are using two different enzymes, there
is a better chance that our fragment contains rspL gene.
Discussion
The primary objective of this project was to create a genomic library using a streptomycinresistant strain of E.coli Top10 (4537 bp) as the genomic DNA, incorporating it into a pUC19
plasmid (2686 bp) vector (Cirino et al., 2003). The successful construction of this genomic
library was expected to confer streptomycin resistance to a recipient E.coli strain Mach1
through the functional selection of the rspL gene (Hanahan, 1983). However, throughout the
experiment, several challenges were encountered, leading to changes in the experimental
design and troubleshooting of errors.
An initial gel electrophoresis performed to confirm the presence of the rspL gene after digestion
of genomic DNA with BamHI resulted in no visible bands. This was primarily due to the low
concentration of the originally isolated genomic Top10 DNA (33.2 ng/µL), which was further
diluted during the digestion reaction and loading of the gel (Inoue et al., 1990). This
concentration was below the minimum detection limit required for the INtRON RedSafeTM
nucleic acid stain to work efficiently (50 ng/µL). As a consequence, no bands were detected,
and the experiment had to be repeated with a new and cleaned up genomic DNA sample.
Subsequent gel electrophoresis performed after digesting the cleaned-up genomic DNA with
BamHI showed successful digestion of the genomic Top10 DNA, as evidenced by a shorter
smear in comparison to the uncut band of the genomic DNA (Sorek et al., 2013). In addition, the
plasmid pUC19 showed two very faint bands after digestion with BamHI, indicating appropriate
digestion of the plasmid as well.
Part B write up 15
Jetul and Japneet April 9, 2023
A ligation reaction was set up using a 1:1 ratio for cut genomic Top10 DNA (insert) and cut
plasmid pUC19 (vector) (Chen & Dubnau, 2004). After overnight incubation at 4 °C, the ligated
product was transformed into Mach1 chemically competent cells. The initial transformation
results were inconclusive due to contamination observed in the positive control plate.
Moreover, the second transformation attempt resulted in an unsuccessful transformation due
to inefficient uptake of DNA by the host organism, which might have been caused by several
factors, such as improper preparation of competent cells, issues concerning the ligation
reaction, or the transformation protocol itself (Inoue et al., 1990).
To increase the likelihood of obtaining a fragment containing the rspL gene, a third gel
electrophoresis was performed using HindIII in addition to BamHI for digesting both genomic
Top10 DNA and plasmid pUC19 (Cirino et al., 2003). The use of two different enzymes would
increase the accuracy of the construct and facilitate the incorporation of the desired fragment
into the plasmid (Hanahan, 1983).
Based on the information provided by the restriction analyzer, the BamHI enzyme cuts at two
different sites on genomic DNA (180 and 2865), producing large fragments that appeared as a
smear in the gel electrophoresis images (Sorek et al., 2013). HindIII was introduced to cut at an
additional site (4130) on genomic DNA, increasing the likelihood that the fragment containing
the rspL gene would be successfully incorporated into the plasmid (Chen & Dubnau, 2004).
In summary, the construction of a genomic library using E.coli Top10 genomic DNA and pUC19
plasmid DNA encountered several challenges throughout the experiment, including low DNA
concentrations, contamination, and inefficient transformation (Inoue et al., 1990). The
introduction of the HindIII enzyme in addition to BamHI for restriction digestion was expected
to increase the probability of obtaining a fragment containing the rspL gene (Cirino et al., 2003).
Furthermore, troubleshooting in each area of competent cells preparation, ligation reaction,
and transformation protocol can assist in identifying and rectifying these challenges, such as reevaluating the insert-to-vector ratio, incubation time, and temperature for the ligation reaction
or testing and optimizing various transformation conditions (Hanahan, 1983).
For this experiment, the most likely problem would be with transformation. It could be
optimized and modified by making changes mentioned below:
a. Temperature and duration: Confirm that the heat shock conditions (e.g. 42°C for 30-45
seconds) are appropriate for your cells (Inoue et al., 1990).
b. Recovery duration: Allow adequate time (usually 1 hour) for the cells to recover and express
the antibiotic resistance marker (Sorek et al., 2013).
c. Optimal antibiotic concentration: Ensure the appropriate concentration of streptomycin for
selection is used on the plates. Too high or low of a concentration may result in inadequate
selection (Chen & Dubnau, 2004).
Part B write up 16
Jetul and Japneet April 9, 2023
In addition to the technical challenges faced during the genomic library construction, human
errors could also have contributed to the unsuccessful or inconclusive results. These errors can
occur in sample handling, reagent preparation, equipment usage, and protocol execution. Such
errors may include:
1. Cross-contamination: During handling of samples, there is potential for cross-contamination
between different DNA samples or between the samples and reagents, leading to undesired
results (Inoue et al., 1990).
2. Reagent preparation: Errors can occur while preparing various reagents such as buffers,
enzyme solutions, or antibiotics. These could include inaccurate measurement or mixing of
components, resulting in incorrect concentrations that can affect experimental outcomes
(Sorek et al., 2013).
3. Pipetting errors: Inaccurate pipetting can lead to incorrect volumes being dispensed, resulting
in the incorrect sample or reagent concentration, which affects the outcome of experiments
(Hanahan, 1983).
4. Equipment usage: Improper operation, maintenance, or calibration of laboratory equipment
can generate unreliable or inconsistent results. For instance, inaccurate temperature settings
for incubation or heat shock can affect the transformation efficiency (Chen & Dubnau, 2004).
To minimize human errors, it is essential to maintain good laboratory practices, maintaining
proper organization of the workspace, labeling samples accurately, and double-checking
reagent concentrations. Additionally, regularly calibrating and maintaining equipment,
following established protocols carefully, and incorporating appropriate controls into
experiments will help reduce the occurrence of human errors and enhance the overall success
of the genomic library construction process.
Future experiments can investigate alternative restriction enzymes, plasmid vectors, and
competent cell strains to improve the overall success of the genomic library construction
process (Cirino et al., 2003). Moreover, ensuring a suitable recovery time for transformed cells,
providing a nutrient-rich medium during recovery, using appropriate plating methods and
conditions, and including positive and negative controls in each transformation experiment will
aid in enhancing the efficiency of the genomic library construction and subsequent functional
selection of the streptomycin resistance-conferring rspL gene (Hanahan, 1983).
Conclusion
Part B write up 17
Jetul and Japneet April 9, 2023
In conclusion, the construction of a genomic library using E.coli Top10 genomic DNA and pUC19
plasmid DNA proved to be challenging due to several factors, including low DNA
concentrations, contamination, and inefficient transformation. Optimization of the
transformation process, selection of alternative restriction enzymes, plasmid vectors, and
competent cell strains could enhance the overall success of the genomic library construction
and subsequent functional selection of the streptomycin resistance-conferring rspL gene.
Future experiments should also emphasize proper controls, recovery conditions, and nutrientrich media to improve the efficiency of this process.

prompt:
Generate the complete UWE Harvard References section for the following essay

Introduction
In recent times, environmental concerns have turned to be a focal point for both consumers and businesses  likewise. accordingly, there's a growing emphasis on green marketing strategies by companies that offer environmentally friendly products. This research aims to explore the impact of green marketing on consumer buying behavior in the manufacturing industry in Nigeria. The study focuses on how consumers ’ appreciations of green products and marketing practices, as well as their motivations,  impact their buying behavior in the Nigerian market.   
Green marketing involves the promotion of environmentally friendly products and services that contribute to sustainable practices. As environmental consciousness continues to accelerate encyclopedically, businesses worldwide are  espousing green marketing strategies to attract customers and gain a competitive edge. Nigeria, with its fast- growing population and expanding economy, represents a significant market for eco-friendly products. still, the relationship between green marketing and consumer buying behavior in Nigeria has not been  considerably studied. thus, this research is  pivotal for companies operating in or looking to enter the Nigerian market, as it examines factors that  impact consumers ’ decisions to buy eco-friendly products. Such insights can be  capitalized by companies to develop  further effective marketing strategies aimed at  compounding their market share and enhancing customer  fidelity. also, this study contributes to the ongoing discourse on sustainable business practices and consumer adoption of green products by providing insights specific to the Nigerian context, making it relevant to researchers, marketers, and policymakers concerned with environmental issues and sustainable consumption patterns.   
The literature review provides an overview of existing knowledge on green marketing and its impact on consumer buying behavior, highlighting gaps that this research aims to address. The theoretical framework and research questions guiding the  research are also introduced. The methodology used in this project is described and justifications are  furnished for the choice of research design, sampling, and data collection  techniques. The limitations of the research design are also addressed, and remedies to overcome them are suggested. The next section presents the findings of the study, including the analysis of research data and a comparison of the findings with the literature reviewed earlier. Incipiently, concluding remarks are provided,  summing up the  crucial findings and their contribution to the existing body of knowledge on green marketing and consumer buying behavior. Furthermore, limitations of the research are identified, suggestions for coming studies are offered, and the practical implications of the findings are discussed. 


Review of the Literature
Green marketing refers to the promotion of products and services with environmentally friendly features, contributing to sustainable development and practices (Peattie & Crane, 2005). Companies have been adopting green marketing strategies in response to the growing environmental consciousness of consumers and the demand for products that align with their eco-friendly values (Rahbar & Wahid, 2011). Green marketing strategies can also provide a competitive edge and foster positive brand associations, resulting in increased consumer loyalty and market share (Chen, 2010). In the context of the manufacturing industry, green marketing strategies encompass a variety of initiatives, such as using eco-friendly materials, energy-efficient production processes, recyclability, and minimizing waste generation (Rahbar & Wahid, 2011). Manufacturers that adopt green marketing strategies often experience enhanced brand reputation, improved consumer loyalty, and increased market success, demonstrating the importance of this approach in today’s sustainability-driven world (Chen, 2010; Peattie & Crane, 2005).

An essential determinant of the success of green marketing initiatives is consumers’ perceptions and awareness of green products (Nguyen et al., 2020). According to the Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991), an individual’s behavior is preceded by their intentions, which are influenced by their attitudes towards the behavior, the relevant subjective norms, and the perceived control they have over performing the behavior. Consequently, positive consumer attitudes and increased awareness of the benefits of green products and practices are critical to translating these attitudes into actual purchase behavior (Biswas & Roy, 2015; Chen, 2020). However, research has identified a gap between pro-environmental attitudes and the actual adoption of green products, which can stem from factors such as lack of information or ineffective green marketing communication, leading to consumer skepticism or greenwashing (Biswas & Roy, 2015; Nguyen et al., 2020). As such, effective communication through green marketing campaigns is crucial to bridge the gap between consumers’ favorable attitudes towards green products and their actual purchase behaviors (Leonidou, 2019).

Environmental concerns have also become increasingly relevant in driving consumer buying behavior, with many consumers considering the ecological implications of their purchase decisions (Dangelico & Vocalelli, 2017). These concerns have led to a willingness from consumers to pay a premium for green products, which in turn has created an opportunity for businesses to cater to this demand (Dangelico & Vocalelli, 2017; Nguyen et al., 2020). Environmental concerns are predominantly driven by factors such as ecological crises, global climate change, and heightened awareness of the environmental repercussions of unsustainable production and consumption (Chen, 2020; Dangelico & Vocalelli, 2017). As such, manufacturers must recognize the significance of environmental concerns in shaping consumer purchasing behavior and strategically position their green products to capitalize on this emerging trend (Dangelico & Vocalelli, 2017). While the existing literature offers an understanding of the impact of green marketing and consumer perception on eco-friendly product adoption, most studies have been conducted in developed countries, where environmental issues may be more pronounced (Nguyen et al., 2020). Thus, there is a need for research focusing on the impact of green marketing on consumer buying behavior in developing nations, such as Nigeria. Factors such as cultural, economic, and regulatory conditions can influence the translation of pro-environmental attitudes into actual purchase behaviors and warrant further exploration.


Theory of Planned Behaviour
The Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) has been widely used in understanding and explaining various human behaviors, including those related to green consumption (Ajzen, 1991). This study applies TPB as the theoretical underpinning to investigate the influence of green marketing on consumer buying behavior in the Nigerian manufacturing industry. According to TPB, intentions play an essential role in shaping individuals’ behavior, and these intentions are influenced by three key factors: attitudes toward the behavior, subjective norms, and perceived behavioral control (Ajzen, 1991). Attitudes refer to the evaluation of the behavior, which may be positive or negative, subjective norms represent the cultural and social pressures an individual perceives in performing the behavior, and perceived behavioral control signifies the individual’s beliefs about their ability to effectively perform the behavior (Ajzen, 1991). The TPB has been successfully applied in previous studies to examine consumer behavior regarding environmentally friendly products and practices (e.g., Biswas & Roy, 2015; Leonidou et al., 2013). These studies have found that positive attitudes towards environmentally friendly products and practices, in conjunction with favorable subjective norms and higher perceived behavioral control, lead to stronger intentions to adopt green products and engage in eco-friendly behavior.

In the context of this study, TPB can be employed to explore how consumers’ attitudes towards green products, the influence of social and cultural norms, and their perceived ability to engage in eco-friendly purchasing behavior interact to shape their intentions and ultimately their adoption of green products in the Nigerian manufacturing industry. By employing the Theory of Planned Behavior as the foundational framework, this study aims to gain a deeper understanding of the complex factors affecting the impact of green marketing on consumers’ purchase behavior while accounting for the specific cultural, economic, and social influences unique to Nigeria.

Research Questions and Hypotheses 
Building upon the existing literature and utilizing the Theory of Planned Behavior, this study aims to address the following research question in the context of the Nigerian manufacturing industry:
RQ: How does green marketing influence consumer buying behavior in the Nigerian manufacturing industry?

To better understand the relationship between green marketing and consumer buying behavior, the following specific research hypotheses have been developed:
H1: Positive consumer attitudes towards green products and their marketing practices enhance the likelihood of purchasing eco-friendly products in Nigeria.
H2: The influence of subjective norms, such as social and cultural pressures, can significantly affect the relationship between green marketing and consumer buying behavior in Nigeria.
H3: Higher perceived behavioral control over engaging in eco-friendly purchasing behavior strengthens the positive impact of green marketing on consumer buying behavior in Nigeria.

By addressing these hypotheses and investigating the research question, this study aims to reveal the intricate interplay of factors affecting the impact of green marketing on consumer buying behavior in Nigeria, while considering the cultural, economic, and social context unique to the country.



Methodology
Identification of paradigm
This study adopts a positivist paradigm, which seeks to formulate precise and quantifiable explanations based on observable empirical evidence (Creswell, 2014). Utilizing a positivist approach allows for the measurement of objective reality through numerical data, providing a scientific and empirically grounded understanding of the impact of green marketing on consumer buying behavior in the Nigerian manufacturing industry context. The adoption of quantitative methods aligns with the positivist paradigm, ensuring that the research outcomes are comparable and generalizable across populations and contexts (Bryman, 2016)

Justification of Chosen Methodology and Methods
Research Design
The decision to employ a cross-sectional survey design for this study is grounded in its ability to efficiently collect data from a large and diverse sample of participants (Bryman, 2016). This design enables the exploration of relationships between green marketing, consumer attitudes, subjective norms, perceived behavioral control, and purchase behavior within the Nigerian manufacturing industry. The cross-sectional approach also allows for the simultaneous examination of multiple variables, providing valuable insights into the intricate interplay of factors affecting consumer buying behavior in response to green marketing initiatives (Creswell, 2014).

Data Collection
To capture a representative sample of the Nigerian population’s perspectives, a self-administered online questionnaire is used as the primary data collection method. This data collection approach allows for efficient and cost-effective access to a geographically diverse sample while offering participants the convenience and flexibility to complete the questionnaire at their own pace (Bryman, 2016). The questionnaire will consist of closed-ended questions, utilizing Likert-scale items to measure respondents’ attitudes towards green products, the influence of subjective norms, perceived behavioral control, and eco-friendly purchase behaviors. This allows for the numerical measurement of participants’ responses, which can be analyzed statistically to determine the relationships between variables (Creswell, 2014). Additionally, the questionnaire will include demographic questions (e.g., age, gender, education, and income), ensuring that the analysis can account for potential variations in consumer behavior based on different population groups. Such demographic information promotes a more nuanced understanding of the factors shaping green marketing’s impact on consumer buying behavior in the Nigerian context (Bryman, 2016).

Sampling
A stratified random sampling technique is employed to ensure a representative and diverse sample drawn from the Nigerian population. This sampling strategy involves dividing the population into distinct and non-overlapping groups or strata based on geographical regions within Nigeria. Participants are then selected randomly from each stratum, resulting in a balanced representation of responses from different areas of the country (Creswell, 2014). By ensuring a geographically diverse sample, this study can account for potential variations in green marketing’s effectiveness and consumer behaviors based on regional differences (Bryman, 2016).

Data Analysis
The data collected through the online questionnaire will be analyzed using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS). Descriptive statistics (e.g., means, standard deviations) will be calculated to present a summary of respondents’ demographic characteristics and their responses to the Likert-scale items. Inferential statistical techniques, such as multiple regression analysis, will be employed to test the research hypotheses and assess the relationships between green marketing, consumer attitudes, subjective norms, perceived behavioral control, and eco-friendly purchase behavior (Creswell, 2014). This comprehensive data analysis approach allows for a robust understanding of the phenomenon under investigation and contributes to the evidence base for green marketing’s impact on consumer buying behavior in developing countries like Nigeria.


Limitations of the Research Design and Potential Remedies
Despite the efficiency and strengths of cross-sectional survey designs, certain limitations need to be acknowledged. First, the self-reported nature of the data may be influenced by social desirability bias, leading participants to overstate their environmentally conscious behaviors (Bryman, 2016). To mitigate this bias, phrasing of questionnaire items should encourage honesty and minimize social desirability influence.

Second, the cross-sectional design does not allow for the establishment of causality between variables, as it captures a snapshot of the population at a particular point in time (Creswell, 2014). However, utilizing the Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991) provides theoretical justification for the expected relationships between variables. To explore causal relationships further, future research could employ longitudinal designs to examine changes in consumer behavior and green marketing interventions over time.

Third, the study’s generalizability may be limited due to the specific focus on the Nigerian manufacturing industry. While the findings will undoubtedly provide valuable insights into the Nigerian context, caution should be exercised when attempting to generalize the results to other industries or countries (Bryman, 2016). Researchers may consider extending the investigation to other industries or countries to explore the broader applicability of the findings.


Findings/Results
Presentation & Discussion of the Analysis of the Research Data
The data collected through surveys and interviews were analysed using descriptive and inferential statistics to understand the impact of green marketing on consumers’ buying behaviour in the Nigerian manufacturing industry. The analysis of the data focused on three thematic codes to delve deeper into the constituents of the said impact – green awareness, attitudes, and purchase behaviour.

Initial descriptive statistics provided a general overview of the demographic profile of the participants, which included their age, gender, educational background, and environmental concern. The results indicate that a majority of participants hold a positive attitude towards the environment showcasing their heightened interest in green initiatives, products, and practices (Smith & Brower, 2012). Findings also depicted that higher-educated consumers exhibited a greater inclination towards sustainable options, corroborating earlier studies in the context of green marketing (Biswas & Roy, 2015).

Subsequently, inferential statistics, such as regression analysis, were employed to assess the relationship between green marketing practices and consumer buying behaviour. The analysis revealed a significant positive relationship between consumers’ perception of green products and their intention to purchase sustainable products (Guagnano, Stern, & Dietz, 1995). Although green marketing strategies were identified as a crucial factor in influencing consumer choices, other factors like cost, product availability, and perceived product quality were also identified to be influential factors (Joshi & Rahman, 2015).

To draw inferences from the data collected, thematic codes derived from the literature review were used. The first theme - green awareness - surfaced as an essential component in driving consumer behaviour in the Nigerian manufacturing industry. The study found that effective green marketing could lead to an increase in consumer awareness and, consequently, promote sustainable consumption (Hamid et al., 2018). This indicates the need for manufacturing companies to invest in educational and promotional campaigns that highlight their green initiatives to target and influence their prospective customer base effectively.

The second theme - attitudes - examined the participants’ underlying beliefs regarding the impact of individual environmental behaviour. Results demonstrated that the majority of respondents considered their consumption choices to be highly influential, which aligns with Ajzen’s (1991) Theory of Planned Behaviour that suggests attitudes can predict behavioural intentions. Additionally, the findings support Grankvist and Biel’s (2007) assertion that individuals with pro-environmental attitudes tend to exhibit more sustainable purchase behaviours, underscoring the importance of fostering such attitudes in target consumers.

Lastly, the third theme, purchase behaviour, discussed the direct impact of green marketing strategies on consumer decisions. Results indicated that green marketing initiatives, such as eco-labelling and green advertising, had a significant positive influence on consumers’ willingness to adopt sustainable practices and support green products (Dangelico & Vocalelli, 2017). Moreover, the findings were consistent with the proposed hypothesis, which stated that consumers’ perception of green products and marketing practices positively affects their buying behaviour.


Discussion of Findings in Relation to the Literature Review and Limitations of Findings 
The findings from this research support and expand upon the existing literature on green marketing and its impact on consumer behaviour. As previously mentioned, the study identified three primary thematic codes through which green marketing strategies could influence consumer purchasing behaviour in the Nigerian manufacturing industry: green awareness, attitudes, and purchase behaviour.

In concurrence with the literature, green awareness emerged as a crucial factor driving consumer behaviour (Peattie & Crane, 2005). The results demonstrate the importance of developing targeted educational and promotional green campaigns aimed at increasing consumer awareness of sustainable practices and initiatives. This aligns with the findings of Alniacik et al. (2011) who emphasize the role of marketing communication in shaping consumer perceptions of green products while effectively bridging the ‘attitude-behaviour gap’.

The second theme - attitudes - supports the theoretical framework that was adopted for the study, Ajzen’s (1991) Theory of Planned Behaviour. According to this theory, a person’s attitude towards a behaviour plays a significant role in determining their behavioural intentions. By establishing a connection between pro-environmental attitudes and purchase behaviour, the findings echo the assertions of Grankvist and Biel (2007) while reinforcing the need to adopt strategies aimed at fostering favourable attitudes towards sustainability within the target audience.

Lastly, the theme of purchase behaviour captures the direct influence of green marketing strategies on consumers’ buying decisions. The significant positive influence of eco-labelling and green advertising on purchasing behaviour, as highlighted by this research, corroborates the findings of earlier studies conducted by Dangelico and Vocalelli (2017) and del Río-González (2005). These results signify the importance of crafting comprehensive green marketing campaigns that effectively inform and persuade consumers to opt for environmentally-friendly options.

Nevertheless, the study has some limitations that need to be recognized. First, the research employed a relatively small sample size, which may have an impact on the generalizability of the results. The findings represent the opinions and perceptions of a selected group and may not necessarily encapsulate the entire consumer audience in Nigeria’s manufacturing industry. Future research could consider a larger and more diverse sample, adding more validity to the findings and enhancing generalizability.

Second, the study solely focused on the Nigerian manufacturing industry, implying that the insights gained may not be applicable across various national contexts or industries. For a more thorough understanding of the scope and impact of green marketing strategies, it is essential to extend the research to other countries and sectors, allowing for cross-comparisons and a comprehensive understanding of consumer behaviour in various contexts.

Lastly, the present research focused primarily on the influence of green marketing strategies on consumers, without delving into the potential barriers to green consumption, such as cost-sensitive behaviour, lack of information access, and limited product availability. Future studies could investigate these inhibiting factors further and evaluate measures employed by organizations to overcome them.

Despite these limitations, the present study contributes significantly to the existing body of knowledge on green marketing and consumer behaviour, focusing on the insights from the Nigerian manufacturing industry.




Conclusion
Overall, the current research project sought to explore the impact of green marketing strategies on consumers’ buying behaviour in the Nigerian manufacturing industry. To achieve this, the study evaluated the existing body of knowledge on green marketing strategies, consumer perception and awareness of green products, and the role of environmental concerns in consumer buying behaviour. The theoretical underpinning was derived from Ajzen’s (1991) Theory of Planned Behaviour, which emphasizes the significance of attitudes, subjective norms, and perceived behavioural control in predicting behavioural intentions.

The research utilized a positivist paradigm, employing a descriptive and correlational research design to gather data through surveys and interviews with a stratified random sample from the Nigerian manufacturing industry. The findings revealed a significant positive relationship between green marketing strategies and consumer buying behaviour. Additionally, three influential factors were identified – green awareness, attitudes, and purchase behaviour – which aligned with the literature review and theoretical framework. The research also corroborated the hypothesis that consumers’ perception of green products and marketing practices positively affect their buying behaviour.

The implications of this research have both academic and practical relevance. Academically, the study enriches the existing literature on green marketing and consumer behaviour, particularly in the context of Nigeria’s manufacturing industry. It provides insight into the direct and indirect impact of green marketing strategies on consumer decisions and identifies potential avenues for future research.

Practically, this research offers valuable implications for organizations in the manufacturing sector seeking to adopt sustainable practices while influencing consumer behaviour. The emphasis on green awareness highlights the need for effective communication and education strategies that can enhance consumers’ understanding of sustainability and motivate them to make eco-friendly choices. Similarly, fostering positive attitudes towards green practices and products by utilizing persuasive marketing techniques like eco-labelling and green advertising can significantly improve consumers’ buying behaviour.

However, it is essential to acknowledge the study’s limitations such as the relatively small sample size and the focus on a single industry within Nigerian manufacturing. Future research could address these limitations by employing a more extensive and diverse sample, as well as exploring different industries and geographical contexts. Additionally, future studies might explore barriers to green consumption and strategies undertaken by organizations to mitigate these challenges.

prompt:
3a
import numpy as np
def trajectory(horizontal_speed, initial_height, xmax, nmax):
    # Define physical parameters
    g = 980  # cm/s^2
    kappa = 0.5  # 1/s
    a = 1  # cm
    b = 0.25  # cm

    # Define step size
    dx = xmax / (nmax - 1)

    # Initialise arrays
    x = np.linspace(0, xmax, nmax)
    y = np.zeros(nmax)
    y[0] = initial_height
    y[1] = y[0] - (g * (1 - np.exp(-(y[0] - a) / b)) * (dx ** 2)) / (2 * (horizontal_speed ** 2))

    # Iterate to compute the rest of the y values
    for n in range(1, nmax - 1):
        y[n + 1] = (-2 * dx ** 2 * g * (1 - np.exp(-(y[n] - a) / b)) + dx * kappa * horizontal_speed * y[
            n - 1] + 4 * horizontal_speed ** 2 * y[n] - 2 * horizontal_speed ** 2 * y[n - 1]) / (
                               2 * horizontal_speed ** 2 + kappa * dx * horizontal_speed)
    return x, y

3b
def residual(horizontal_speed, initial_height, x_teacup, y_teacup, nmax):
    # Compute the trajectory of the ball using the given parameters
    x, y = trajectory(horizontal_speed, initial_height, x_teacup, nmax)

    # Compute the residual as the difference between the final y-value and the target y-value
    residual = y[-1] - y_teacup

    return residual


3c
import math
from scipy.optimize import bisect

def find_horizontal_speed(initial_height, x_teacup, y_teacup, nmax, bounce=False):
    # Define physical parameters
    g = 980  # cm/s^2

    # Compute the initial guess for u0 based on the parabolic trajectory
    h = initial_height - y_teacup
    u0_guess = x_teacup * math.sqrt(g / (2 * h))

    # Define the bracketing interval for the root-finding algorithm
    lower_bound = 0.8 * u0_guess
    upper_bound = 1.2 * u0_guess

    # Define the residual function F(u0) for a given horizontal speed u0
    def F(u0):
        return residual(u0, initial_height, x_teacup, y_teacup, nmax)

    # Find the root of F(u0) using the bisection method with a tolerance of 0.1cm
    u0_root = bisect(F, lower_bound, upper_bound, xtol=0.1)

    return u0_root

Modify your function find_horizontal_speed() from Task 3c, so that it computes   with exactly 1 bounce of the marble before it lands into the cup when bounce is set to True.
Use a tolerance of no more than 0.1cm.
Strategy
In the bounce case, the interaction with the floor produces unpredictable results. However, we know that friction always reduces the motion, and the interaction with the floor produces most of the damping (also true with real objects).
However, we can pretend there is exactly zero damping, which gives us an estimate that will undershoot the mark when we include friction.
In this case, we estimate that the marble falls to the floor with a parabolic trajectory. It then bounces back and returns to its original height with a mirror-image trajectory. After that, the marble continues to fall toward the target but with a reduced distance.
Putting everything together, produces a lower bound for the speed estimate. The zero-bounce estimate from Task 3c now gives us an upper bound, and we can bracket our solution with:
((xteacup*sqrt(g/(2h)))/(1+2*sqrt(y0/h))) < u0 < xteacup*sqrt(g/(2h)) where h=y0-yteacup
Starting from this interval [umin,umax], it's possible to use a modified version of the bisection method,which also counts the total number of bounces and peaks for the trajectory with the midpoint umidpoint=(umin+umax)/2.
You can then choose the next half-interval based on this information.The constraints are as follows:
 - The marble must bounce exactly once before getting into the cup.
 - The marble must fall downwards into the cup.

Career Training provides qualifications in various subject areas, including business, community services, information technology and hospitality. There are currently 400 students enrolled across a wide range of courses. There are 35 staff members, including training staff and administration.

The levels of qualifications provided are as follows:

Certificates I, II, III and IV
Diploma

It seeks feedback from students and internal staff every month and conducts internal audits of the company’s policies and procedures to ensure compliance against the standards for registered training organisations.

Career Training aims to provide the highest quality and research-based vocational business education and facilitate a conducive environment to develop the global mindsets of students

Jetul and Japneet April 9, 2023
Image 1: Picture of first 1% gel electrophoresis performed to confirm the presence of rspL gene
after digestion of genomic DNA with BamHI
The above image was captured from UV light analysis of the 1% agarose gel prepared in 1X TAE
buffer with 2.5 µL INtRON RedSafeTM and 6X loading dye. The well labelled 1 was utilized for
1Kb plus DNA ladder RTU (FroggoBI0- BIOHELIX), 5 µL loaded as standard whilst the well
labelled 2 contains the digested genomic DNA (10 µL digested sample + 2 µL loading dye). The
above gel electrophoresis was run at 120 V for 20 minutes. Genomic uncut was not loaded
which was considered an error. Moreover, there were no bands at all and the problem was low
concentration of genomic DNA.
It was noticed that since INtRON RedSafeTM requires at minimum 50 ng/ µL of the sample
concentration to give any visualization detection effects, the above gel electrophoresis was
unsuccessful. This is because the concentration of originally isolated genomic Top10 DNA was
already quite low with 33.2 ng/ µL and while preparing the digestion reaction with total volume
of 35 µL we used 10 µL of the genomic DNA which implies that our genomic was diluted. Not
only this when we loaded 10 µL digested sample with 2 µL loading dye it further diluted. As per
this, the concentration of loaded sample was 33.2 ng/ µL which is very less than 50 ng/ µL as
per the RedSafeTM to work efficiently.
Calculations of digested sample concentration:
(33.2 ng / µL × 10 µL in digestion) / (10 µL while loading) = 33.2 ng/ µL

at 120 V under UV light. This is the seconds gel that contained new digestion reaction

Jetul and Japneet April 9, 2023
The above image represents the picture captured of 1% gel electrophoresis run for 25 minutes
at 120 V under BIORAD Imager. The gel was prepared in 1X TAE buffer with 2.5 µL INtRON
RedSafeTM along with 6X loading dye used for sample preparations. Gel was shared with

(FroggoBI0- BIOHELIX) , well 5 contained the uncut genomic Top10 (5 µL + 6X loading dye)

band of genomic in lane 5 hence suggest the digestion to be complete and well 7 contains the

mg/mL X-gal, and 8 µL of 500 mM IPTG. Negative control © contains 50 µL of competent cells.
Positive control (A) contains 50 µL of competent cells and 5 µL of pUC19. Experiment plates are

Image 5: Transformation results containing experiment results and controls after 24-hour

Jetul and Japneet April 9, 2023

plates (A,B) in duplicate contain the contents as mentioned in Image 4 above The experiment
was not successful due to plating issue. There is inefficient uptake of DNA by host organism
which led to inefficient transformation that mean unsuccessful transformation.
Part B write up 12
Jetul and Japneet April 9, 2023
